Translation: I bought a stale cake (lit: stale sweet bread).
Comment: There are three possible nominal modification methods for intransitive predicate-class lexical items in Gitxsan. One is with the attributive marker -m, and takes place prenominally. (Forbes_2012, p.50)

Source: adopted from (Forbes_2012, p. 50, ex. 1) & (Forbes_2012, p. 55, ex. 16b)
Comment: Requires that a predicate-class item follow it(modifier) as the object of modification.

Source: adopted from (Forbes_2012, p. 50, ex. 1) & (Forbes_2012, p. 55, ex. 16c)
Comment: Attributive modifiers are also strictly prenominal.
"Adjective-type" predicates tend to relativizie in the prenominal position (Forbes_2012, p. 50).
"Verb-type" predicates tend to relativizie in the postnominal position (Forbes_2012, p. 50).

Translation: The small swimming green frog is clever.
Comment: Relative clauses utilizing eventive predicates tend to occur postnominally (Forbes_2012, p. 59).

Translation: Intended: 'The small swimming green frog is clever.'
Comment: While prenominal placement of these eventive relative clauses is sometimes acceptable, more frequently it is rejected or considered awkward by speakers (Forbes_2012, p. 59).

Translation: I talked with the clever child.
Intended: 'I talked with the clever child.'
Comment: Most stative intransitive predicates are obligatorily positioned prenominally (Forbes_2012, p. 60).

Translation: The hat you're wearing is green.
Intended: 'The hat you're wearing is green.'
Comment: The relative clauses of transitive predicates, in contrast, always position themselves following the noun (Forbes_2012, p. 60).

Gloss: small small=CN small house on mountain
Translation: The house on the montain is very small.

Gloss: give-TR-1SG.II=CN bone OBL=CN dog sit-SX DIST
Translation: I gave a bone to the sitting dog.

Gloss: give-TR-1SG.II=CN bone OBL=CN dog who=CN sit-SX
Translation: I gave a bone to the sitting dog.
the fish the old man ate
